document.text: We see that a movement has been started to put into the field an independent ticket against the nominees of the Democratic Party, nominated according to the primary election law of the State of VhginM, and who are entitled to the support of every Democrat in the county. We the Democra tic. County Committee, therefore address this appeal to the Democratic voters of the county. The Democratic Party is in power in the Nation, State and County. By reason of the splendid and patriotic administration of President Wilson it is likely to re main in power in the nation for years to come. By reason of its splendid administration in State affairs for many years, its lease on power in the State of Virgina is indefinite. No less indefinite is the control of Appomattox County by that Party, because its control has enured -to the benefit of the people and the upbuilding of the county. Since 1902 there has been no serious opposition to the Democratic party in tjhis county and the result has been a great development in our county along all lines. Ve notice published in the Times-Virginian, a call is made by Dr. D. Mott Robertson inviting the people to attend a meeting at Appomattox Court House on Friday, August 20th, for the pur pose of nominating a full ticket in opposition to the ticket nominated in the Democratic primary. This movement purports to be by independents but from the personnel of the leaders it smacks of Republicanism. The call invites all voters of the county to attend who believe in low taxes the election of Dis trict School superintendents and school trustees by the people who are opposed to the issuing of county bonds and who favor the one-room schools having as long session as the other schools. These are general propositions, without details of how their accomplishment can be brought about, and probably many of the voters are in favor ,of one or more of them. Certainly everybody is in favor of a lower tax rate if the governmental affairs can be run on such a rate without seriously impairing the progress of the State or County. Many of our citizens are in favor of election of district school superintendents and school trus tees by the people, and we have no doubt if a sufficient number of citizens would so petition, the re presentative ot this county would introduce in the Legislature an amendment to the Constitution providng for the election of district school superintendents by the people, and upon a similar petition would introduce a bil in the legislature providing for the election of school trustees by the people. There is no question before the people as to the issue of county bonds as there is no need for or demand for such an issue in bur county. We have no doubt every citizen of Appomattox would be in favor of the one-room schools having as long sessions as the other schools of the county if that could be done without increasing the rate of taxation or reducing the length of session of the other schools. The call is inconsistent in that on one hand he advocates lower taxation and on the other a larger expenditure for school purposes. You may get one but you cannot get both you cant have longer school sessions without paying an additional amount of money for them and this money comes in the shape of taxes from the people. Our Democratic Nominees will go before the voters at the November election upon their re cords with the belief that the masses of the people, who think at all, have approved and will ratify their policy by reelecting them. Neither will the voters be misled by any insinuations and fault-find ing proclamations, of that coterie of citizens who are out of office, and public favor, and who are seek ing an issue upon which to get in. We appeal to the Democrats and the thoughtful independent voters not to allow the Republican leaders of the county and a lew disappointed Democrats to lead them into the Republican party.

A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight.
